Text: As the deer pants for streams of water, so my soul pants for You, O God.
Context: This verse sets the tone of deep spiritual longing that defines the psalm as a whole.

Text: My soul thirsts for God, for the living God. When can I go and meet with God?
Context: The psalmist intensifies the sense of spiritual thirst to be in the presence of God.

Text: My tears have been my food day and night, while men say to me all day long, "Where is your God?"
Context: The contrast between the psalmist's inward thirst for God and external taunts from others.

Text: These things I remember as I pour out my soul: how I would go with the throng and lead them in procession to the house of God, with glad shouts and songs of praise, a multitude keeping festival.
Context: Recollection of past worship experiences brings a mix of joy and pain amidst the current distress.

Text: Why are you downcast, O my soul? Why so disturbed within me? Put your hope in God, for I will yet praise Him for the salvation of His presence.
Context: An emotional plea from the psalmist to his own soul, recommending hope even in despair.

Text: O my God, my soul is downcast within me; therefore I remember You from the land of the Jordan, from the heights of Hermon, from Mount Mizar.
Context: Despite internal turmoil, the psalmist finds a degree of comfort in recalling God's presence in specific locations.

Text: Deep calls to deep in the roar of Your waterfalls; all Your breakers and Your waves have swept over me.
Context: The psalmist uses the metaphor of overwhelming waters to describe his feelings of being engulfed by troubles.

Text: By day the LORD directs His love, at night His song is with meâ€” a prayer to the God of my life.
Context: In the midst of distress, the psalmist acknowledges God's steadfast love and guidance.

Text: I say to God my rock, "Why have You forgotten me? Why must I go about mourning, oppressed by the enemy?"
Context: A piercing question to God that expresses a sense of abandonment and grief.

Text: With a shattering bone my adversaries taunt me, while they say to me all day long, "Where is your God?"
Context: The taunts of adversaries add to the psalmist's sense of suffering and desperation.

Text: Why are you downcast, O my soul? Why so disturbed within me? Put your hope in God, for I will yet praise Him, my Savior and my God.
Context: The psalmist again addresses his soul, encouraging himself to maintain hope and continue to praise God despite his current feelings.

Text: My soul is downcast within me; therefore I will remember You from the land of the Jordan and the peaks of Hermon, from Mount Mizar.
Context: Reiteration of the solace found in God amidst a backdrop of emotional struggle, emphasizing the act of remembrance as a comfort.
